question: The open science movement is NOT attempting to make science…
Which of the following does NOT belong under the umbrella of open science?
Which of these benefits does open access bring?
choice1: Application of your findings by practitioners and policy makers
choice2: Researchers in developing countries have access to your work
choice3: Your research gets more exposure and increases chance of getting future funding
choice4: Easy increase of your scientist impact factor

question: Which of these claims about open data is NOT true?
choice1: Data can be accessed and shared.
choice2: Data that can be accessed and reused by anyone for any purpose without technical or legal restrictions.
choice3: Data can be reused free of charge.
choice4: Data can be sold to other interested parties.

question: What is NOT a common condition found in data licences?
Which of the following is NOT one of the main benefits of documenting your code?
choice2: Others can utilise and extend your code
choice3: To get credited if others use your code
choice4: Influence on the performance of your code

question: Which of the claims about an embargo period on data access is NOT correct?
choice1: An embargo period is often stated in your consortium agreement, funders’ contract, patent, etc.
choice2: An embargo period is usually created as a result of unfavourable political or economic circumstances between nations.
choice3: An embargo period is temporary and at the end of it data will become available by either open or mediated access.
choice4: An embargo period allows for IP registration (patent, design, copyright).

question: What should be included in a data management plan (DMP)?
Which of the following is NOT a FAIR principle?
Which type of metadata is NOT the relevant to the FAIR principles:
What is NOT the function of data repositories?
Which services provide data centres additional to those of data repositories?
Which of the following factors are addressed by open science policies?
choice1: Restriction and anonymisation of personal data

question: Which of the following belongs to general principles of scientific integrity?
What is your study plan referred to after a journal reviews it?
What is a pre-print?
choice1: A copy of the research hypotheses you have for your research
choice2: An infographic which sums up your research
choice3: A full draft of a paper sent for peer-review
